Short_Description: Impetigo (im-puh-TIE-go) is a common and highly contagious skin infection that mainly affects infants and children. Impetigo usually appears as red sores on the face, especially around a child's nose and mouth, and on hands and feet. The sores burst and develop honey-colored crusts.
Long_Description: Impetigo is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection that primarily affects children but can occur in individuals of any age. It is caused by bacteria, most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes, which enter the skin through cuts, insect bites, or other breaks in the skin barrier. The infection typically presents as red sores or blisters that can quickly rupture, ooze fluid, and form a honey-colored crust. Impetigo often appears around the nose and mouth but can spread to other areas of the body through scratching or contact with contaminated objects. Symptoms may include itching and discomfort in the affected areas. Diagnosis is usually based on the appearance of the skin lesions, and treatment often involves topical antibiotics for mild cases or oral antibiotics for more extensive infections. Good hygiene practices, such as handwashing and keeping lesions clean, are essential in preventing the spread of impetigo. Although the condition is usually not serious and can be effectively treated, prompt attention is necessary to avoid complications and limit transmission to others.
Keyfacts: Impetigo is a very common skin infection that causes skin sores and blisters. Impetigo is caused by staphylococcus or streptococcus bacteria. Impetigo usually affects young children, as the infection can easily spread in places such as schools and childcare centres â€” this is why it is sometimes called â€˜school soresâ€™. Your doctor can diagnose impetigo by looking at your sores and may also take a swab to test for bacteria. Impetigo is usually treated with antibiotics in the form of a cream, ointment, tablets or syrup, depending on the severity of the condition .

Short_Description: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a break in the inner lining of the stomach, the first part of the small intestine, or sometimes the lower esophagus. An ulcer in the stomach is called a gastric ulcer, while one in the first part of the intestines is a duodenal ulcer.
Long_Description: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) refers to the formation of open sores or ulcers in the lining of the stomach, small intestine, or esophagus. These ulcers develop when the protective mucous layer is compromised, allowing stomach acid to damage the underlying tissue. The most common causes of peptic ulcers are infection with Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) bacteria and the prolonged use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen and aspirin. Symptoms of peptic ulcer disease can include burning stomach pain, bloating, indigestion, nausea, and in severe cases, vomiting blood or passing dark, tarry stools. Diagnosis typically involves a combination of medical history, physical examination, and tests such as endoscopy or breath tests to detect H. pylori. Treatment usually focuses on reducing stomach acid and eradicating H. pylori infection, often through a combination of antibiotics and acid-reducing medications. Lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and stress management, are also important in managing the condition. While peptic ulcers can be effectively treated, if left untreated, they can lead to serious complications such as bleeding, perforation, and gastric obstruction.
Keyfacts: A duodenal ulcer is a sore in the lining of part of your small intestine. You may experience stomach pain, bloating or feeling sick with a duodenal ulcer. Eating food might help, but some foods can make it worse. A duodenal ulcer can be caused by helicobacter pylori bacteria or certain medicines that harm the protective lining of your small intestine. A duodenal ulcer is a sore in the lining of part of your small intestine. You may experience stomach pain, bloating or feeling sick with a duodenal ulcer. Eating food might help, but some foods can make it worse. A duodenal ulcer can be caused by helicobacter pylori bacteria or certain medicines that harm the protective lining of your small intestine.
Medicine: omeprazole (Prilosec), lansoprazole (Prevacid), rabeprazole (Aciphex), esomeprazole (Nexium) and pantoprazole (Protonix)

Short_Description: The common cold is a viral infection of your nose and throat (upper respiratory tract). It's usually harmless, although it might not feel that way. Many types of viruses can cause a common cold.
Long_Description: The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, primarily caused by rhinoviruses, although other viruses such as coronaviruses and adenoviruses can also be responsible. Symptoms typically include a runny or stuffy nose, sore throat, cough, sneezing, mild headache, and fatigue, often accompanied by a low-grade fever. Colds are highly contagious and can spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes, as well as by touching contaminated surfaces and then touching the face. While the common cold generally resolves on its own within a week to ten days, it can lead to more serious complications in individuals with weakened immune systems or pre-existing respiratory conditions. There is no specific cure for the common cold; treatment focuses on alleviating symptoms, which may include rest, hydration, over-the-counter medications, and home remedies. Preventative measures, such as frequent handwashing, avoiding close contact with sick individuals, and maintaining good hygiene, can help reduce the risk of contracting or spreading the virus.
Keyfacts: A cold is a viral infection that usually affects your nose and throat. Common symptoms include sore throat, sneezing and a blocked or runny nose. Symptoms usually get better on their own within 7 to 10 days. There are self-care treatments and medicines that can help you feel better when you have a cold. Key facts A cold is a viral infection that usually affects your nose and throat. Common symptoms include sore throat, sneezing and a blocked or runny nose. Symptoms usually get better on their own within 7 to 10 days. There are self-care treatments and medicines that can help you feel better when you have a cold.

Short_Description: Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It can cause an itchy, blister-like rash. The rash first appears on the chest, back, and face, and then spreads over the entire body, causing between 250 and 500 itchy blisters.
Long_Description: Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus, characterized by an itchy rash, red spots, and fluid-filled blisters that eventually crust over. It primarily affects children but can occur in individuals of any age, particularly those who have not been vaccinated or previously infected. The disease spreads through direct contact with the rash or via respiratory droplets from coughing or sneezing by an infected person. Symptoms typically appear 10 to 21 days after exposure and may include fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, and headache, followed by the development of the characteristic rash. While chickenpox is usually mild in children, it can lead to complications such as bacterial skin infections, pneumonia, and, in rare cases, encephalitis, especially in adults and those with weakened immune systems. Diagnosis is generally based on the appearance of the rash and accompanying symptoms, with treatment focusing on symptom relief through antihistamines and fever reducers. Vaccination is the most effective means of prevention, significantly reducing the risk of infection and its complications, and the virus can reactivate later in life, causing shingles.
Keyfacts: Chickenpox is a very contagious infection caused by the varicella zoster virus. The most common symptom of chickenpox is an itchy red rash with fluid-filled blisters. Most cases of chickenpox are mild and get better on their own. Serious complications of chickenpox include infected blisters, pneumonia and meningitis. Vaccination is the best way to protect yourself against chickenpox. Key facts Chickenpox is a very contagious infection caused by the varicella zoster virus. The most common symptom of chickenpox is an itchy red rash with fluid-filled blisters. Most cases of chickenpox are mild and get better on their own. Serious complications of chickenpox include infected blisters, pneumonia and meningitis. Vaccination is the best way to protect yourself against chickenpox.

Precaution_1: use heating pad or cold pack
Short_Description: Cervical spondylosis is a general term for age-related wear and tear affecting the spinal disks in your neck. As the disks dehydrate and shrink, signs of osteoarthritis develop, including bony projections along the edges of bones (bone spurs).
Long_Description: Cervical spondylosis is a degenerative condition affecting the cervical spine, or neck, characterized by the wear and tear of the intervertebral discs and the cervical vertebrae. It is often associated with aging, as the spinal discs lose hydration and elasticity over time, leading to the formation of bone spurs and the potential narrowing of the spinal canal. Symptoms can vary widely and may include neck pain, stiffness, headaches, and in some cases, radiating pain, numbness, or weakness in the arms or hands if nerve roots are compressed. Risk factors for cervical spondylosis include age, genetics, previous neck injuries, and occupations that involve repetitive neck motions or prolonged periods of neck strain. Diagnosis typically involves a physical examination, medical history, and imaging studies such as X-rays or MRIs to assess structural changes in the cervical spine. Treatment options range from conservative approaches like physical therapy, pain management with medications, and lifestyle modifications to more invasive procedures in severe cases, such as corticosteroid injections or surgery. While cervical spondylosis is a common condition, effective management can significantly improve quality of life and reduce discomfort.
Keyfacts: Upper back pain is pain or discomfort that involves the bones, joints, muscles, nerves or any other body tissue in or around your thoracic spine. Your thoracic spine is the area between your neck (cervical spine) and lower back (lumbar spine). Most upper back pain has no specific cause â€” usually, upper back pain isnâ€™t caused by a serious medical problem. Back pain often goes away on its own, and there are many things you can do (such as exercise, stress and weight management) to help manage your pain until it resolves. Your doctor may recommend or prescribe medicines for a short time to help you return to regular daily activities.
Medicine: Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB), naproxen sodium (Aleve) and acetaminophen (Tylenol)

Short_Description: Hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid) occurs when your thyroid gland produces too much of the hormone thyroxine. Hyperthyroidism can accelerate your body's metabolism, causing unintentional weight loss and a rapid or irregular heartbeat.
Long_Description: Hyperthyroidism is a condition characterized by the overproduction of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland, leading to an accelerated metabolism and a range of symptoms. It can result from various causes, including Graves' disease (an autoimmune disorder), toxic nodular goiter, or thyroiditis. Common symptoms of hyperthyroidism include increased heart rate, weight loss despite an increased appetite, anxiety, irritability, tremors, heat intolerance, excessive sweating, and changes in menstrual patterns. In some cases, individuals may also experience goiter, which is an enlargement of the thyroid gland. Diagnosis is typically made through blood tests that measure levels of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). Treatment options vary depending on the cause and severity of the condition and may include antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine therapy, or in some cases, surgery to remove part or all of the thyroid gland. Effective management of hyperthyroidism is essential to prevent complications such as heart problems, osteoporosis, and thyroid storm, a rare but life-threatening condition. Regular monitoring and follow-up care are crucial for individuals with hyperthyroidism to ensure optimal thyroid function and overall health.
Keyfacts: The thyroid is a gland in the neck, near the base of the throat, that helps control some of your body’s metabolic processes. Hyperthyroidism (sometimes called thyrotoxicosis or overactive thyroid) is when your thyroid gland is overactive. The most common symptoms of hyperthyroidism are feeling anxious or nervous, being unable to tolerate heat, having heart palpitations, feeling tired and losing weight. To diagnose hyperthyroidism, your doctor will examine you and send you for a blood test to measure the levels of your thyroid hormones. Hyperthyroidism can be treated with medications, radioactive iodine therapy or surgery.

Short_Description: Urinary tract infection: An infection of the kidney, ureter, bladder, or urethra. Abbreviated UTI. Not everyone with a UTI has symptoms, but common symptoms include a frequent urge to urinate and pain or burning when urinating.
Long_Description: A urinary tract infection (UTI) is an infection that occurs in any part of the urinary system, which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra. UTIs are most commonly caused by bacteria, with Escherichia coli (E. coli) being the most frequent culprit. Symptoms typically include a strong, persistent urge to urinate, a burning sensation during urination, frequent urination with only small amounts of urine, cloudy or strong-smelling urine, and pelvic pain. In some cases, particularly when the infection reaches the kidneys, symptoms may also include fever, chills, nausea, and back pain. UTIs are more common in women due to anatomical differences, but men can also be affected, especially with age or underlying health issues. Diagnosis is usually made through a urine sample, which is tested for the presence of bacteria and white blood cells. Treatment typically involves antibiotics to eliminate the infection, and drinking plenty of fluids can help flush out bacteria. Preventive measures include proper hydration, urinating after sexual intercourse, and maintaining good hygiene. While UTIs are generally treatable, recurrent infections may indicate underlying health issues that require further evaluation.
Keyfacts: Infections of your urinary tract (also known as UTIs) are common. Bladder infections are the most common type of UTI. If you have symptoms of a UTI, see your doctor or pharmacist as soon as possible for treatment.
Medicine: trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim, Bactrim DS), fosfomycin (Monurol), nitrofurantoin (Macrodantin, Macrobid, Furadantin), cephalexin and ceftriaxone

Precaution_1: lie down flat and raise the leg high
Short_Description: A vein that has enlarged and twisted, often appearing as a bulging, blue blood vessel that is clearly visible through the skin. Varicose veins are most common in older adults, particularly women, and occur especially on the legs.
Long_Description: Varicose veins are swollen, twisted veins that are visible just under the surface of the skin, most commonly occurring in the legs and feet. They arise when the valves within the veins weaken or become damaged, leading to poor blood flow and pooling of blood. Factors contributing to the development of varicose veins include age, genetics, obesity, pregnancy, prolonged standing or sitting, and hormonal changes. Symptoms can range from mild to severe and may include aching, heaviness, fatigue in the legs, swelling, and in some cases, skin changes or ulcers near the affected veins. While varicose veins are often considered a cosmetic concern, they can lead to more serious complications, such as blood clots or chronic venous insufficiency. Diagnosis is typically made through a physical examination, and imaging tests like ultrasound may be used to assess blood flow. Treatment options vary depending on the severity of the condition and can include lifestyle changes, compression stockings, sclerotherapy, laser treatments, and in more severe cases, surgical procedures to remove or close the affected veins. Managing varicose veins is important for reducing symptoms and preventing potential complications.
Keyfacts: Varicose veins are swollen blood vessels under your skin. They develop if your veins are damaged and blood pools in your legs instead of flowing up to your heart. Varicose veins can cause leg pain and sometimes ulcers or blood clots. If you have varicose veins, avoid standing for long periods, wear compression stockings, try to exercise, and lose weight if you are overweight. Injection therapy, laser and surgery can treat varicose veins.

Short_Description: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). By damaging your immune system, HIV interferes with your body's ability to fight infection and disease.
Long_Description: AIDS, or Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome, is a severe and chronic condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which attacks and weakens the immune system, specifically the CD4 T cells that are crucial for fighting infections. When the immune system becomes significantly compromised, individuals become vulnerable to opportunistic infections and certain cancers, marking the progression from HIV infection to AIDS. Symptoms of AIDS can include rapid weight loss, recurring fever, extreme fatigue, prolonged swelling of the lymph nodes, and the presence of opportunistic infections or unusual cancers. HIV is primarily transmitted through unprotected sexual contact, sharing needles, and from mother to child during childbirth or breastfeeding. Diagnosis is made through blood tests that detect HIV and measure the immune system's health. While there is currently no cure for AIDS, antiretroviral therapy (ART) can effectively manage HIV infection, allowing individuals to live longer, healthier lives and reducing the risk of transmission. Prevention strategies, including safe sex practices, needle exchange programs, and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), are vital in controlling the spread of HIV. Early diagnosis and continuous treatment are crucial in managing the disease and improving outcomes for those affected.
Keyfacts: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that affects your immune system by destroying CD4 cells. You are at a higher risk of getting HIV if you have unprotected sex, share needles, already have another STI and get a piercing or tattoo with unsterile equipment. Untreated HIV usually leads to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) within 10 years. HIV can be diagnosed by doing a blood test. Antiretroviral therapy is very effective treatment for HIV; if you take your treatment properly, you can live a long and healthy life with HIV. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that affects your immune system by destroying CD4 cells. You are at a higher risk of getting HIV if you have unprotected sex, share needles, already have another STI and get a piercing or tattoo with unsterile equipment. Untreated HIV usually leads to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) within 10 years. HIV can be diagnosed by doing a blood test. Antiretroviral therapy is very effective treatment for HIV; if you take your treatment properly, you can live a long and healthy life with HIV.

Short_Description: Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is when blood suddenly bursts into brain tissue, causing damage to your brain. Symptoms usually appear suddenly during ICH. They include headache, weakness, confusion, and paralysis, particularly on one side of your body.
Long_Description: Paralysis resulting from a brain hemorrhage occurs when there is bleeding in or around the brain, often due to a ruptured blood vessel. This condition can lead to significant neurological damage, depending on the location and extent of the hemorrhage. Symptoms may vary widely and can include sudden weakness or numbness on one side of the body, difficulty speaking, loss of coordination, and changes in consciousness. The paralysis may affect the arms, legs, or face, and it can be temporary or permanent, depending on the severity of the hemorrhage and the speed of medical intervention. Common causes of brain hemorrhage include high blood pressure, head trauma, aneurysms, and blood vessel malformations. Diagnosis is typically made through imaging studies such as CT scans or MRIs, which can identify the presence of bleeding and assess its impact on brain function. Treatment may involve medications to control blood pressure and reduce swelling, as well as surgical interventions to repair damaged blood vessels or relieve pressure on the brain. Rehabilitation, including physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy, is often necessary to help individuals regain function and adapt to any lasting effects of paralysis. Timely medical attention is crucial for improving outcomes and minimizing long-term complications associated with brain hemorrhage.
Keyfacts: A stroke occurs when your brain can’t get enough oxygen and important nutrients. This is usually because a blood clot or sudden bleed reduces the blood supply. Signs of a stroke can include a drooping face, difficulty moving your arm(s), or slurred speech. If you notice signs of a stroke, call triple zero (000) immediately, since any delay may lead to permanent brain damage or death. You can reduce your chance of having a stroke by managing risk factors such as high blood pressure and cholesterol. Eating healthily and exercising will also help.
Medicine: labetalol, phenytoin (dilantin), methylprednisolone, baclofen, warfarin and rivaroxaban

Short_Description: An acute illness characterized by fever caused by infection with the bacterium Salmonella typhi. Typhoid fever has an insidious onset, with fever, headache, constipation, malaise, chills, and muscle pain. Diarrhea is uncommon, and vomiting is not usually severe.
Long_Description: Typhoid fever is a serious bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi, which is transmitted through contaminated food and water. The disease is characterized by a prolonged fever, weakness, abdominal pain, headache, and loss of appetite, often accompanied by constipation or diarrhea. Symptoms typically develop 6 to 30 days after exposure to the bacteria and can escalate if not treated promptly. In severe cases, complications such as intestinal perforation or septicemia can occur, posing significant health risks. Diagnosis is usually made through blood cultures or stool tests to confirm the presence of the bacteria. Treatment primarily involves antibiotics to eliminate the infection, and supportive care may be necessary to manage symptoms and prevent dehydration. Prevention strategies include practicing good hygiene, ensuring safe drinking water, and obtaining the typhoid vaccine, especially for individuals traveling to areas where the disease is prevalent. While typhoid fever is treatable, early diagnosis and appropriate intervention are crucial to reducing the risk of complications and ensuring a full recovery.
Keyfacts: Typhoid fever and paratyphoid fever are caused by different species of salmonella bacteria. The bacteria that cause typhoid fever and paratyphoid fever is commonly spread through sewage-contaminated food and water. Typhoid fever can become life-threatening if it's not treated. Symptoms of both illnesses include fever, abdominal pain and headache. Vaccination is recommended for people travelling to areas where typhoid is present and where food and water may be contaminated.
Medicine: ciprofloxacin (levoflaxin or ofloxacin), ceftriaxone (cefotaxime or cefixime), azithromycin and carbapenems

Short_Description: Hepatitis B is an infection of your liver. It can cause scarring of the organ, liver failure, and cancer. It can be fatal if it isn't treated. It's spread when people come in contact with the blood, open sores, or body fluids of someone who has the hepatitis B virus.
Long_Description: Hepatitis B is a viral infection caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV) that primarily affects the liver, leading to inflammation and potential long-term liver damage. The virus is transmitted through contact with the blood or bodily fluids of an infected person, commonly through unprotected sexual contact, sharing needles, or from mother to child during childbirth. Many individuals with hepatitis B do not exhibit symptoms, especially in the early stages, but when symptoms do occur, they may include fatigue, jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), abdominal pain, dark urine, and loss of appetite. Acute hepatitis B can resolve on its own, but for some, it can progress to chronic hepatitis B, which increases the risk of developing serious complications such as cirrhosis, liver failure, and liver cancer. Diagnosis is typically made through blood tests that detect HBV antigens and antibodies. While there is no specific cure for hepatitis B, antiviral medications can help manage chronic infection and reduce the risk of liver damage. Vaccination is an effective preventive measure, providing immunity against the virus. Regular monitoring and medical care are essential for individuals living with hepatitis B to manage their health and prevent complications.
Keyfacts: Hepatitis B is a viral infection that affects the liver. Symptoms of hepatitis B include dark urine, nausea and fatigue. However, many people have no symptoms at all. Hepatitis B infection can either be acute (when the illness lasts for less than 6 months), or chronic (the illness lasts for longer than 6 months). Hepatitis B can be prevented with vaccination. Key facts Hepatitis B is a viral infection that affects the liver. Symptoms of hepatitis B include dark urine, nausea and fatigue. However, many people have no symptoms at all. Hepatitis B infection can either be acute (when the illness lasts for less than 6 months), or chronic (the illness lasts for longer than 6 months). Hepatitis B can be prevented with vaccination.

Precaution_2: use detol or neem in bathing water
Short_Description: In humans, fungal infections occur when an invading fungus takes over an area of the body and is too much for the immune system to handle. Fungi can live in the air, soil, water, and plants. There are also some fungi that live naturally in the human body. Like many microbes, there are helpful fungi and harmful fungi.
Long_Description: Fungal infections are caused by the overgrowth of fungi, which can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, nails, and internal organs. These infections can range from superficial, such as athlete's foot and ringworm, to more serious systemic infections that can impact individuals with weakened immune systems. Common types of fungal infections include dermatophyte infections (affecting the skin and nails), candidiasis (caused by the Candida species, often affecting the mouth, throat, and genital area), and aspergillosis (a respiratory infection caused by Aspergillus species). Symptoms vary depending on the type and location of the infection but may include redness, itching, swelling, and the presence of rashes or lesions. Diagnosis typically involves a physical examination, medical history, and laboratory tests such as cultures or skin scrapings. Treatment options range from topical antifungal creams and oral medications to more aggressive therapies for systemic infections. Preventive measures include maintaining good hygiene, keeping skin dry, and avoiding close contact with infected individuals. While most fungal infections are treatable, prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are essential to prevent complications, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
Keyfacts: Fungal infections are any disease or condition you get from a fungus. They usually affect your skin, hair, nails or mucous membranes but they can also infect your lungs or other parts of your body. You’re at higher risk for fungal infections if you have a weakened immune system. Antifungal medications are usually used to treat fungal infections.
Medicine: clotrimazole (Canesten), econazole, miconazole, terbinafine (Lamisil), fluconazole (Diflucan), ketoconazole (Daktarin), nystatin (Nystan) and amphotericin

Short_Description: Inflammation of the liver due to the hepatitis C virus (HCV), which is usually spread via blood transfusion (rare), hemodialysis, and needle sticks. The damage hepatitis C does to the liver can lead to cirrhosis and its complications as well as cancer.
Long_Description: Hepatitis C is a viral infection caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV) that primarily affects the liver, leading to inflammation and potential liver damage. The virus is transmitted through contact with infected blood, commonly through sharing needles, unsafe injection practices, and, less frequently, through sexual contact or from an infected mother to her baby during childbirth. Many individuals with hepatitis C may not exhibit symptoms initially, but when they do occur, symptoms can include fatigue, jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), abdominal pain, dark urine, and loss of appetite. Diagnosis is typically made through blood tests that detect antibodies to HCV and measure viral RNA levels. Hepatitis C can be acute or chronic; while acute infections may resolve spontaneously, chronic hepatitis C can lead to serious complications such as cirrhosis, liver failure, and liver cancer. Treatment has advanced significantly, with direct-acting antiviral medications offering a cure for most chronic cases within 8 to 12 weeks. Preventive measures emphasize reducing exposure to the virus, such as using sterile needles and practicing safe sex, while regular monitoring and medical care are essential for managing health and preventing complications.
Keyfacts: Hepatitis C is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus. Itâ€™s spread by contact with an infected personâ€™s blood, such as through sharing needles or some sexual activities. Many people with hepatitis C donâ€™t have any symptoms until their liver is damaged. Itâ€™s estimated that 8 out of 10 new cases of hepatitis C in Australia result from the unsafe injecting of drugs. There are very effective treatments available for hepatitis C infection. Key facts Hepatitis C is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus. Itâ€™s spread by contact with an infected personâ€™s blood, such as through sharing needles or some sexual activities. Many people with hepatitis C donâ€™t have any symptoms until their liver is damaged. Itâ€™s estimated that 8 out of 10 new cases of hepatitis C in Australia result from the unsafe injecting of drugs. There are very effective treatments available for hepatitis C infection.

Short_Description: A migraine can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine attacks can last for hours to days, and the pain can be so severe that it interferes with your daily activities.
Long_Description: Migraine is a neurological condition characterized by recurrent, severe headaches often accompanied by various symptoms, including nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, and visual disturbances known as aura. These headaches typically occur on one side of the head and can last from a few hours to several days, significantly impacting daily activities. The exact cause of migraines is not fully understood, but they are believed to involve changes in brain chemistry and blood flow, with triggers that may include stress, hormonal changes, certain foods, environmental factors, and lack of sleep. Diagnosis is primarily based on a patientï¿½s medical history and symptom description, as there are no specific tests for migraines. Treatment options range from over-the-counter pain relievers for mild cases to prescription medications for more severe attacks, including triptans and preventive therapies aimed at reducing the frequency and intensity of migraines. Lifestyle modifications, such as maintaining a regular sleep schedule, staying hydrated, and managing stress, can also help minimize the frequency of migraine attacks. While migraines can be debilitating, effective management strategies can greatly improve quality of life for those affected.
Keyfacts: Migraine is a common problem, involving severe headaches, nausea, vomiting or sensitivity to light or sound. You might get an aura before the headache starts, where you may see flashing lights or have trouble talking. Migraine attacks can have many different triggers, such as stress, missing meals, eating certain foods, hormonal changes or not getting enough sleep. When a migraine attack starts, sleeping in a dark, quiet room and taking pain-relieving medicines straight away, may stop the attack. If you get migraines often, maintaining a healthy lifestyle and taking a preventive medicine can make them less frequent and severe.

Short_Description: Bronchial asthma is a medical condition which causes the airway path of the lungs to swell and narrow. Due to this swelling, the air path produces excess mucus making it hard to breathe, which results in coughing, short breath, and wheezing. The disease is chronic and interferes with daily working.
Long_Description: Bronchial asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to difficulty in breathing. It is often triggered by various environmental factors such as allergens (like pollen, dust mites, and pet dander), irritants (such as smoke and strong odors), respiratory infections, exercise, and changes in weather. Common symptoms include wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath, and chest tightness, which can vary in frequency and severity. Asthma attacks may occur suddenly and can be life-threatening if not managed properly. Diagnosis typically involves a combination of medical history, physical examination, and lung function tests, such as spirometry, to assess the degree of airway obstruction. Treatment focuses on controlling symptoms and preventing attacks through the use of inhaled corticosteroids, bronchodilators, and avoiding known triggers. Long-term management often includes the development of an asthma action plan, regular monitoring, and education on proper inhaler techniques. While asthma is a lifelong condition, effective management allows many individuals to lead healthy and active lives.
Keyfacts: Asthma is a long-term lung condition that is caused by narrowing of the airways when they become inflamed. The most common symptoms of asthma are: wheezing, coughing, feeling â€˜out of breathâ€™ and tightness in the chest. Symptoms are usually mild, but they can flare up. This can cause an â€˜asthma attackâ€™ and may require hospital care. There are effective medicines for asthma that will help you feel well and keep you out of hospital, when taken correctly. Asthma can be managed. Preventer medicines can prevent symptoms. Reliever inhalers treat your symptoms and help when you have an asthma attack. Asthma is a long-term lung condition that is caused by narrowing of the airways when they become inflamed. The most common symptoms of asthma are: wheezing, coughing, feeling â€˜out of breathâ€™ and tightness in the chest. Symptoms are usually mild, but they can flare up. This can cause an â€˜asthma attackâ€™ and may require hospital care. There are effective medicines for asthma that will help you feel well and keep you out of hospital, when taken correctly. Asthma can be managed. Preventer medicines can prevent symptoms. Reliever inhalers treat your symptoms and help when you have an asthma attack.

Short_Description: Alcoholic hepatitis is a diseased, inflammatory condition of the liver caused by heavy alcohol consumption over an extended period of time. It's also aggravated by binge drinking and ongoing alcohol use. If you develop this condition, you must stop drinking alcohol
Long_Description: Alcoholic hepatitis is a serious condition characterized by inflammation of the liver caused by excessive alcohol consumption. It can occur in people who drink heavily over a prolonged period, but it can also develop in those with a shorter history of heavy drinking. Symptoms often include jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and fatigue. Severe cases can lead to complications such as liver failure, ascites (fluid accumulation in the abdomen), and hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and altered mental state due to liver dysfunction). Diagnosis is typically made through a combination of medical history, physical examination, blood tests to assess liver function, and imaging studies. Treatment primarily involves abstaining from alcohol, which is crucial for recovery, along with supportive care to manage symptoms and nutritional support. In some cases, corticosteroids may be prescribed to reduce liver inflammation. Early intervention and lifestyle changes are essential for improving outcomes and preventing further liver damage, as alcoholic hepatitis can progress to more severe liver disease or cirrhosis if not addressed promptly.
Keyfacts: Alcohol-induced hepatitis is inflammation of the liver caused by alcohol use. Too much alcohol overloads the liver with toxins that injure the tissues. People with this condition should ask their healthcare providers for help to quit drinking in order to prevent further liver damage.

Precaution_3: eat fruits and high fiberous food
Short_Description: Yellow staining of the skin and sclerae (the whites of the eyes) by abnormally high blood levels of the bile pigment bilirubin. The yellowing extends to other tissues and body fluids. Jaundice was once called the "morbus regius" (the regal disease) in the belief that only the touch of a king could cure it
Long_Description: Jaundice is a medical condition characterized by the yellowing of the skin and the sclera (the white part of the eyes) due to an excess of bilirubin, a yellow pigment produced during the breakdown of red blood cells. It can be a sign of various underlying health issues, primarily related to liver function, bile duct obstruction, or hemolysis (the rapid breakdown of red blood cells). Jaundice can be classified into three main types: pre-hepatic (caused by increased bilirubin production from hemolysis), hepatic (due to liver diseases such as hepatitis, cirrhosis, or liver cancer), and post-hepatic (resulting from bile duct obstruction, such as gallstones or tumors). Symptoms accompanying jaundice may include dark urine, pale stools, itching, and fatigue. Diagnosis typically involves blood tests to measure bilirubin levels and assess liver function, along with imaging studies to identify potential obstructions or liver damage. Treatment depends on the underlying cause; for instance, addressing liver disease, relieving bile duct obstructions, or managing hemolytic conditions. Early diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.
Keyfacts: Jaundice is when your skin and the whites of your eyes turn yellow. Itâ€™s caused by the build-up of a substance called bilirubin in your blood. There are many causes of jaundice. Itâ€™s important to see your doctor as soon as possible if you think you might have jaundice.
Medicine: iron supplements, antihistamines, cholestyramine, rifampin and naltrexone

Short_Description: A rare form of liver inflammation caused by infection with the hepatitis E virus (HEV). It is transmitted via food or drink handled by an infected person or through infected water supplies in areas where fecal matter may get into the water. Hepatitis E does not cause chronic liver disease.
Long_Description: Hepatitis E is a viral infection caused by the hepatitis E virus (HEV), primarily transmitted through the consumption of contaminated water or food. It is most common in areas with poor sanitation and is often associated with outbreaks, particularly in developing countries. Symptoms typically appear 2 to 10 weeks after exposure and can include fatigue, fever, nausea, abdominal pain, and jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes). While hepatitis E usually causes an acute infection that resolves on its own, it can be particularly severe in pregnant women, potentially leading to complications such as fulminant liver failure. Diagnosis is generally confirmed through blood tests that detect HEV antibodies or viral RNA. There is no specific antiviral treatment for hepatitis E; management focuses on supportive care, including hydration and rest. Preventive measures emphasize improving sanitation, access to clean water, and proper food handling practices. While hepatitis E is often self-limiting, awareness and prompt management are important, especially in high-risk populations.
Keyfacts: Hepatitis E is a liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus (HEV). Hepatitis E is common in many parts of the world where sanitation is poor. Most people recover fully from hepatitis E without any complications. Hepatitis E can only be diagnosed with laboratory tests.

Short_Description: an acute infectious disease caused by a flavivirus (species Dengue virus of the genus Flavivirus), transmitted by aedes mosquitoes, and characterized by headache, severe joint pain, and a rash. â€” called also breakbone fever, dengue fever.
Long_Description: Dengue is a viral infection transmitted primarily by Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti, and is prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions. The infection can cause a wide range of symptoms, from mild to severe, including high fever, severe headache, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding such as nosebleeds or gum bleeding. In some cases, dengue can progress to severe dengue, which may lead to serious complications like organ failure and severe bleeding. The incubation period typically lasts 4 to 10 days after a mosquito bite, and diagnosis is made through blood tests that detect the virus or antibodies. While there is no specific antiviral treatment for dengue, management focuses on supportive care, including hydration and pain relief, while avoiding non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to reduce bleeding risks. Preventive measures include mosquito control, using insect repellent, and wearing protective clothing, along with vaccines available in some countries for individuals at risk. Awareness and prevention are crucial in controlling the spread of dengue, especially in endemic areas.
Keyfacts: Dengue fever is caused by the dengue virus. You can catch dengue fever when a mosquito infected with dengue virus bites you. Most people who have dengue fever recover in about a week, but sometimes the infection is more serious. Dengue fever is caused by the dengue virus. You can catch dengue fever when a mosquito infected with dengue virus bites you. Most people who have dengue fever recover in about a week, but sometimes the infection is more serious.

Short_Description: Hepatitis D, also known as the hepatitis delta virus, is an infection that causes the liver to become inflamed. This swelling can impair liver function and cause long-term liver problems, including liver scarring and cancer. The condition is caused by the hepatitis D virus (HDV).
Long_Description: Hepatitis D is a viral infection caused by the hepatitis D virus (HDV), which only occurs in individuals already infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV). It is considered a satellite virus because it requires the presence of HBV to replicate. Hepatitis D can worsen the severity of hepatitis B infections, leading to increased liver inflammation and a higher risk of cirrhosis and liver cancer. Transmission of HDV occurs through contact with infected blood, similar to hepatitis B, and can also be spread through unprotected sexual contact and from mother to child during childbirth. Symptoms of hepatitis D can resemble those of hepatitis B, including fatigue, jaundice, abdominal pain, dark urine, and loss of appetite. Diagnosis is typically made through blood tests that detect HDV antibodies and assess liver function. Treatment options are limited; managing hepatitis D often involves controlling the underlying hepatitis B infection, usually with antiviral medications. Prevention primarily focuses on hepatitis B vaccination, as preventing HBV infection also prevents HDV infection. Awareness and timely medical intervention are crucial for individuals at risk of hepatitis D, particularly those with chronic hepatitis B.
Keyfacts: Hepatitis D is a liver disease caused by the hepatitis D virus (HDV). Only people with hepatitis B can contract HDV. Hepatitis B vaccination provides protection against hepatitis B and, therefore, against hepatitis D. People with hepatitis D show severe symptoms of the disease.

Short_Description: The death of heart muscle due to the loss of blood supply. The loss of blood supply is usually caused by a complete blockage of a coronary artery, one of the arteries that supplies blood to the heart muscle.
Long_Description: A heart attack, or myocardial infarction, occurs when blood flow to a part of the heart is blocked, typically by a blood clot in a coronary artery. This blockage prevents oxygen-rich blood from reaching the heart muscle, leading to damage or death of heart tissue. Common risk factors include high blood pressure, high cholesterol, smoking, diabetes, obesity, a sedentary lifestyle, and a family history of heart disease. Symptoms of a heart attack can vary but often include chest pain or discomfort, shortness of breath, nausea, lightheadedness, and pain that may radiate to the arms, back, neck, or jaw. Immediate medical attention is critical, as prompt treatment can restore blood flow and minimize heart damage. Diagnosis usually involves physical examinations, electrocardiograms (ECGs), and blood tests to check for heart damage markers. Treatment may include medications to dissolve clots, procedures like angioplasty to open blocked arteries, or surgery such as coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). Preventive measures focus on lifestyle changes, including a heart-healthy diet, regular exercise, and managing risk factors. Early recognition of symptoms and rapid response can significantly improve outcomes for individuals experiencing a heart attack.
Keyfacts: A heart attack occurs when the blood supply to your heart is blocked and your heart muscle canâ€™t get enough oxygen. Common symptoms of a heart attack are chest pain, feeling breathless and sweating. Heart attacks are mostly caused by coronary heart disease. You can reduce your risk of having a heart attack by adopting a healthy lifestyle. severe getting worse, or lasting longer than 10 minutes A heart attack occurs when the blood supply to your heart is blocked and your heart muscle canâ€™t get enough oxygen. Common symptoms of a heart attack are chest pain, feeling breathless and sweating. Heart attacks are mostly caused by coronary heart disease. You can reduce your risk of having a heart attack by adopting a healthy lifestyle. severe getting worse, or lasting longer than 10 minutes
Medicine: aspirin, thrombolytics, heparin, nitroglycerin, morphine, beta blockers, ace inhibitors and statins

Short_Description: Pneumonia is an infection in one or both lungs. Bacteria, viruses, and fungi cause it. The infection causes inflammation in the air sacs in your lungs, which are called alveoli. The alveoli fill with fluid or pus, making it difficult to breathe.
Long_Description: Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus, leading to symptoms such as cough, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing. It can be caused by various pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi. The most common bacterial cause is Streptococcus pneumoniae, while viral pneumonia can often result from infections like influenza or COVID-19. Symptoms can vary from mild to severe and may include chest pain, fatigue, and a productive cough that produces phlegm. Diagnosis typically involves a physical examination, medical history, chest X-rays, and sometimes blood tests or sputum cultures to identify the causative agent. Treatment depends on the type of pneumonia and its severity; bacterial pneumonia is usually treated with antibiotics, while viral pneumonia may require antiviral medications and supportive care. Preventive measures include vaccination against influenza and pneumococcal bacteria, as well as practicing good hygiene and avoiding smoking. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial for improving outcomes, especially in high-risk populations such as the elderly, young children, and individuals with compromised immune systems.
Keyfacts: Pneumococcal disease is a bacterial infection caused by streptococcus pneumoniae. The bacteria are easily spread through coughing, sneezing, saliva and mucus. Your symptoms can range from mild to severe, depending on where the infection is in your body. Pneumococcal disease can be treated with antibiotics. The best protection against pneumococcal disease is vaccination.
Medicine: antibiotics (Azithromycin, Amoxicillin, Levofloxacin), antivirals (Oseltamivir, Acyclovir) and antifungals (Fluconazole, Voriconazole)

Short_Description: Arthritis is the swelling and tenderness of one or more of your joints. The main symptoms of arthritis are joint pain and stiffness, which typically worsen with age. The most common types of arthritis are osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
Long_Description: Arthritis is a term encompassing a range of inflammatory joint conditions that lead to pain, stiffness, swelling, and reduced range of motion. The most common types include osteoarthritis, a degenerative joint disease caused by wear and tear on the cartilage, and rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the joints, resulting in chronic inflammation. Symptoms can vary but typically feature joint pain, tenderness, and stiffness, often worsening in the morning or after periods of inactivity. Diagnosis involves medical history, physical examination, imaging tests, and lab tests to determine the specific type of arthritis. Treatment options include pain-relief medications, physical therapy, lifestyle changes, and sometimes surgical procedures to repair or replace damaged joints. Regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, and stress management are also crucial for symptom relief. While arthritis is a chronic condition, effective management can greatly enhance the quality of life for those affected.
Keyfacts: Arthritis is the name for a group of conditions that affect the joints in your body. It causes damage to your joints, usually resulting in discomfort and pain. There are many different types of arthritis, and treatment depends on the type. Arthritis is the name for a group of conditions that affect the joints in your body. It causes damage to your joints, usually resulting in discomfort and pain. There are many different types of arthritis, and treatment depends on the type.
Medicine: buprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve)

Precaution_1: stop eating solid food for while
Precaution_2: try taking small sips of water
Short_Description: Gastroenteritis is an inflammation of the digestive tract, particularly the stomach, and large and small intestines. Viral and bacterial gastroenteritis are intestinal infections associated with symptoms of diarrhea , abdominal cramps, nausea , and vomiting .
Long_Description: Gastroenteritis, often referred to as the stomach flu, is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines caused by viral, bacterial, or parasitic infections. Common viruses include norovirus and rotavirus, while bacteria such as Escherichia coli and Salmonella can also be culprits. Symptoms typically include diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and dehydration. The condition is highly contagious, spreading through contaminated food or water, close contact with infected individuals, or surfaces contaminated with pathogens. Diagnosis is usually based on medical history and symptoms, although stool tests may be conducted to identify specific pathogens. Treatment primarily focuses on hydration to prevent dehydration, with oral rehydration solutions recommended for mild cases. In more severe cases, intravenous fluids may be necessary. While gastroenteritis often resolves on its own within a few days, preventive measures, such as practicing good hygiene, proper food handling, and vaccination (for rotavirus), are key to reducing the risk of infection. Most individuals recover fully, but it is important to monitor for signs of severe dehydration, particularly in young children and the elderly.
Keyfacts: Gastroenteritis ('gastro') is a common and very contagious illness that can affect your stomach and intestines, causing vomiting and diarrhoea. Babies under 6 months should always see a doctor if you think they may have gastro. Treatment of gastroenteritis includes drinking fluids to avoid dehydration â€” your doctor might not need to prescribe medicines. Reduce your risk of catching or spreading gastro by washing your hands well after using the bathroom, changing nappies and before handling food or eating. Children and adults should not return to school or work until 48 hours after the last episode of diarrhoea and/or vomiting. Medicine: loperamide link (Imodium) and bismuth subsalicylate link (Pepto-Bismol, Kaopectate)

Short_Description: Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease usually caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) bacteria. Tuberculosis generally affects the lungs, but can also affect other parts of the body. Most infections show no symptoms, in which case it is known as latent tuberculosis.
Long_Description: Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs but can also impact other parts of the body. TB spreads through the air when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks, releasing tiny droplets that contain the bacteria. Symptoms of active TB often include a persistent cough, chest pain, weight loss, fever, night sweats, and fatigue. Some individuals may have latent TB, where the bacteria remain inactive in the body without causing symptoms but can reactivate later. Diagnosis typically involves a combination of skin tests, blood tests, chest X-rays, and sputum tests to detect the bacteria. Treatment for TB usually requires a lengthy course of multiple antibiotics, typically lasting six to nine months, to effectively eliminate the infection and prevent the development of drug-resistant strains. Adherence to the treatment regimen is crucial for successful recovery. Preventive measures include vaccination with the Bacillus Calmette-Guï¿½rin (BCG) vaccine in certain populations, as well as improving living conditions and access to healthcare. While TB is a preventable and treatable disease, it remains a significant global health challenge, particularly in areas with high rates of infection and limited healthcare resources.
Keyfacts: Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease that can affect any part of your body, most commonly your lungs. TB can be latent (where you donâ€™t have any symptoms and are not infectious), or active (where you are unwell). The tuberculin skin test or a blood test can check if you have been infected with TB. TB can be treated with a combination of antibiotics that you will need to take for at least 6 months. The BCG vaccine prevents you becoming very unwell with TB, but it is only recommended in Australia for people at high risk of exposure to TB.
